Award.AwardTitle: Robust Post-Selection Inference with Application to Subgroup Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers have been facing challenges from high-dimensional data that contain many different characteristics for each subject. For example, biomedical scientists analyze tens of thousands of genomes to determine the cause of disease and find the most promising treatments; social scientists study differential policy impacts by leveraging vast amounts of personal data gathered from social media. This project lays out two lines of research aimed at developing valid statistical inference in this challenging environment. The insights and tools developed from this project would contribute to the advancement of a wide variety of other disciplines, including economics, education, health care, and biomedical sciences. In addition, graduate students will be engaged in the project to study the statistical guarantees and to develop relevant software packages for the research. Since the project develops modern statistical methodologies with substantial applications, it will be suitable for training graduate students with a broad range of skills.

This project addresses two research problems and seeks to provide insights, theory and tools for more informed decision making in high dimensions. The first problem focuses on studying the treatment effect heterogeneity. Quantification and characterization of heterogeneous treatment effects play an increasingly important role in evaluating the efficacy of social programs and medical treatments in the presence of high-dimensional covariates. In particular, the research will develop efficient procedures for estimating heterogeneous quantile treatment effects and subgroup average treatment effects via covariate balancing. The second problem focuses on studying the validity and invalidity of data splitting for conducting inference with high-dimensional data. The project will address the issue of “random-splitting bias” in estimating the regression coefficients when the number of dummy/imbalanced variables is sizable. To overcome this challenge, the project will develop a guided data splitting framework that splits the data into more balanced halves. Because the usage of random data splitting goes beyond post-selection inference, the framework developed and the possible solutions derived from it are broadly applicable to many data-driven investigations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research has significantly advanced the frontiers of modern statistical methodology, particularly in high-dimensional de-biased inference and post-selection inference for estimating heterogeneous treatment effects. Beyond theoretical innovations, this work has produced practical tools that benefit a range of fields, including economics, biomedical science, and applied statistics.


The project’s primary outcome was the development of advanced statistical methods and statistical inference frameworks for analyzing heterogeneous treatment effects in high-dimensional data. These treatment effects were explored through multiple perspectives, including the conditional average treatment effect, subgroup treatment effect, and heterogeneous quantile treatment effect. The resulting methods address the unique complexities of high-dimensional data, providing researchers with innovative tools to understand causal relationships when treatments have varying effects across heteroegeous study populations. With these tools, practitioners can access powerful computational resources to address real-world issues in fields such as causal inference in economics and biomedical research, supporting more effective and data-driven decision-making.


Educationally, this project made a substantial impact by training the next generation of researchers. A Ph.D. student, Waverly Wei, played a pivotal role in the research, gaining extensive experience in advanced statistical methodologies. Under the support of this award, Dr. Wei successfully defended her dissertation in 2023 and has since taken a faculty position at a leading research university, furthering the reach of this project’s methods and insights. Furthermore, the PI served as an invited speaker and panelist in the School of Public Health Data Science Workshop. This workshop is dedicated to high school students from local schools, particularly those who are underrepresented minorities and come from low-income families with limited access to data science resources. The PI presented the research conducted under the support of this award on causal inference and participated in a panel discussion, offering encouragement and advice to high school students interested in data science and statistics.


Moreover, inspired by this project, I developed a new course on machine learning for public health students at UC Berkeley, which was well received. The course included topics on causal inference, high-dimensional inference, post-selection challenges, and methods for analyzing treatment effect heterogeneity. This hands-on course provided students with the skills needed to navigate high-dimensional data analysis, equipping them for impactful careers in research and industry.


To maximize the accessibility and impact of the research, the PI has shared research results broadly. The project resulted in several published research articles and two open-source R packages for subgroup analysis, making these tools widely available to the research community. In addition to publications, the PI has actively disseminated our findings through presentations at major conferences and seminars, further encouraging the adoption of these methodologies across disciplines. These outreach efforts have facilitated the use of our methods in diverse fields, helping to realize the project’s full potential and practical impact.
